awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Thermal Investigation of Strain-Tuned Thermal Conductivities of Thin Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Strained nanofilms are widely used in electronic and optoelectronic devices, microelectromechanical systems, photovoltaics, light-emitting diodes, and for solid-state energy conversion. However, the thermal properties of a strained film have not yet been systematically investigated. This collaborative project aims to study the impact of a high tensile strain (up to 1-10% depending on the film thickness) on the thermal properties of representative thin films that are of technologically important materials in current electronic industry. Outcomes of this work can particularly benefit their broad industrial applications with the preference of thin-film geometry for device fabrication. More broadly, the obtained knowledge can be potentially generalized to other nanostructured materials for strain-engineered properties. This project can benefit a general public through materials discoveries at museum exhibitions, development of interdisciplinary education and research programs at two universities, and creation of new outreach activities to K-12 and high-school students. 

This proposed work will establish a comprehensive understanding on the thermal properties of ?elastic strain engineered? nanofilms, with an emphasis on the thermal anisotropy along both the tensile-strain and the transverse directions. A series of systematic temperature-dependent thermal transport studies will be carried out on representative thin films under uniaxial and equi-biaxial tensile strains, via the integration of the state-of-the-art ultrafast pump-probe experimental technique and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. New physical insights will be gained, particularly, into the usually overlooked transverse-direction phonon transport. In addition, by tuning the spot sizes and frequencies of laser heating in the pump-probe experiments, the in-plane phonon mean-free-path (MFP) spectrum will also be reconstructed. Such a phonon MFP spectrum will be further used for the phonon transport analysis of strained films, in comparison with numerous studies on unstrained bulk materials. The knowledge gained from thin-film studies can be potentially extended to other nanostructures (e.g., nanowires and 2D materials) and nanostructured bulk materials (e.g., nanocomposites hot pressed under an ultrahigh pressure).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The research goal of this collaborative proposal is to study the impact of a 1-10% tensile strain on the thermal transport in representative thin films. In the literature, numerous simulations can be found for strain-dependent thermal conductivities of various micro/nano-structures, but experimental validation is rare. One measurement for Si thin films was carried out in air (i.e., with convection influence) and the employed Raman thermometry is not accurate in the temperature reading [Murphy, PhD dissertation, University of Pennsylvania, 2014]. This project provides more reliable strain-dependent thermal conductivities of a Si micro-film, using 3 omega measurements for a suspended sample in a high vacuum. The developed sample holder can be used for other materials (e.g., polymer fibers) for strain-related studies. 

Besides the thermal properties, strains also play an important role in nanofabrication, such as annealing treatment to change the nanopore sizes across a thin film. In our study, the nanopore contraction under high-temperature annealing can be suppressed by a SiO2 substrate, due to the poor wettability of molten Si on SiO2. When the film is suspended, the nanopores would suddenly shrink due to the residual stress/strain and sometimes the film may be broken. Now it is acknowledged that strain/stress introduced by a substrate can be used to influence the crystal growth of a thin film and change the properties of a film. More studies should be carried out along this direction.

Broader impacts: Multiple undergraduate students have gained valuable research experience out of the project. One PhD student was graduated and two more will graduate soon.  At the fundamental level, a better scientific understanding of the strain-property relationship can provide important guidance for “elastic strain engineering” that is widely used to tune the thermal, ionic, electrical, catalytic, and optical properties of materials for various applications, including high-power and high-voltage electronics, thermoelectrics, photovoltaics, and spintronics.

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2022
Modified by: Qing Hao

Images (1 of )
  • Left: A holder to apply tensile strains to a suspended thin film. Right: Measurement data in comparison with simulations and another measurement.
    Qing Hao
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Qing Hao
    Sample holder and measurement results
  • Substrate-Suppressed Nanopore Contraction during Annealing
    Qing Hao
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)

    Annealing of Nanoporous Films
